title: Deception Lab
text:
Deception










Definition


A “process by which one individual deliberately attempts to convince another person to accept as true what the liar knows to be false, typically for the liar […] to gain some type of benefit or to avoid loss”
— Vrij (2008, p.15)

title: Deception Lab
text:
Early Approaches

1960s: Emotional leakage

Liars experience guilt/fear → emotions “leak”

Bodily movements leak more than the face

(Ekman & Friesen, 1969)


1980s: Cognitive load

Liars must inhibit truth + invent consistent stories

(Zuckerman et al., 1981; Hartwig et al., 2014)

title: Deception Lab
text:
Judgement Biases

Truth bias

People judge others truthful more often than they are

(Bond & DePaulo, 2006, meta-analysis)


Explanations

Spinozan mind — belief is automatic (Gilbert, 1991)

Truth-Default Theory — default to truth (Levine, 2014)

Adaptive Lie Detector — functional decision-making (Street, 2015)

title: Deception Lab
text:
Accuracy in Lie Detection

No diagnostic cues

No reliable behavioural signal found (DePaulo et al., 2003)


Human performance

~54% accuracy (chance = 50%) (Bond & DePaulo, 2006)

Training, confidence, or profession → little effect (Aamodt & Custer, 2006)

title: Deception Lab
text:
Recent Developments

Active elicitation techniques

Strategic questioning, cognitive load, verifiability

(Nahari, 2019; Vrij & Granhag, 2012)

title: Deception Lab
section: Defining Lying: The Role of Intention
text:
Defining Lying: The Role of Intention

Intentionality central in most definitions

(Chisholm & Feehan, 1977; DePaulo et al., 2003; Fallis, 2012)


Debates:

Smith (2007): lying = preventing truth, even without intent to mislead

Peterson (1995): intentionality is necessary


Broad definition allows exploration across different contexts

title: Deception Lab
text:
How Often Do People Lie?

Diary studies (DePaulo et al., 1996):

Students reported ~2 lies per day

20–31% of interactions involve deception


Dispersion matters:

Most people tell few/no lies

A small group = “prolific liars” tell most lies

~5% of people → ~50% of lies (Serota et al., 2010, 2021)


Truth is the default: most people tell the truth most of the time

title: Deception Lab
section: Why Do People Lie? Motives & Taxonomies
text:
Why Do People Lie? Motives & Taxonomies

Lie aversion:

People often forgo gains to avoid lying (Abeler et al., 2012; Gneezy, 2005)

Motivations: intrinsic honesty, guilt, reputation


Self vs. Other / Gain vs. Loss taxonomy (DePaulo, 1996; Vrij, 2008)

Self-interest vs altruism, advantage vs avoiding loss


Examples:

“Butler lies” to maintain relationships (Hancock, 2009)

More willing to lie for charity vs self (Yin et al., 2017)

title: Deception Lab
text:
Individual & Cultural Influences

Pathological lying: compulsive, not goal-driven

Possible causes: low self-esteem, neurocognitive deficits (Poletti, 2011)


Prolific liars:

Score high in Machiavellianism, manage consistency (Kashy & DePaulo, 1996; El Haj, 2017)


Culture matters:

Collectivist cultures → more likely to lie to protect relationships (Bessarabova, 2014; Park, 2018)

Individualist cultures → prioritise integrity


Moral compass:

Frequent liars not necessarily less moral (Halevy, 2014)

title: Deception Lab
text:
Meso-Level Accounts of Lying

Meso level = liar + recipient interaction

Vrij et al. (2019) review → 3 key accounts:

Moral psychology (Bond & DePaulo, 2006)

Self-presentational theory (DePaulo, 1992; Goffman, 1959)

Interpersonal Deception Theory (IDT) (Buller & Burgoon, 1996)

title: Deception Lab
text:
Moral Psychology Account

People judge others’ lies as immoral but view their own lies as excusable/circumstantial

Cheating research shows:

People forget/justify moral rules when dishonest (Shu et al., 2011; Shalvi et al., 2015)


Distancing from moral responsibility → self-serving evaluations

More research needed (Vrij et al., 2019)

title: Deception Lab
text:
Self-Presentational Theory

Both liars and truth-tellers aim to appear credible (DePaulo, 1992)

Truth-tellers: use eye contact, smiling (e.g., job interviews) (Bolino et al., 2008)

Liars: selective lies to manage impressions (e.g., online dating profiles) (Toma & Hancock, 2010)

Liars describe more strategies for impression management than truth-tellers (Hartwig et al., 2007)

Self-deception: lying to oneself to better convince others (Trivers, 2011)

title: Deception Lab
text:
Interpersonal Deception Theory (IDT)

Focuses on dynamic interaction between liar and recipient

Behaviour is adjusted in real time based on partner feedback (Buller & Burgoon, 1996)

Example: desert survival task (Burgoon et al., 2010)

Real-time discussion → greater trust, more successful deception


Liars often seek to control the conversation (Burgoon et al., 2014)

Neuro evidence: deception engages theory of mind & monitoring of others (Christ et al., 2009)

title: Deception Lab
text:
The Psychological Costs of Lying

Leakage hypothesis (Ekman & Friesen, 1969):

Emotions (fear, anxiety) may “leak” via body more than face

Exception: micro-expressions (Ekman, 1985)


Criticism: truth-tellers may also show anxiety (Vrij et al., 2006; Brennen & Magnussen, 2020)

title: Deception Lab
text:
Deception as Cognitively Effortful

Four-factor theory (Zuckerman et al., 1981):

Cognitive load, emotional experience, behaviour control, physiological arousal


Deception requires:

Inhibiting truth

Constructing coherent false story


Evidence:

fMRI → overlap with executive function areas (Christ et al., 2009)

EEG → greater preparation signals in liars (Dong & Wu, 2010)

Behaviour → longer response latencies; time pressure promotes honesty (Suchotzki et al., 2017)

title: Deception Lab
text:
Cognitive Processes of Lying

Deception = recombining memories, not pure invention (Hume, 1748/2007)

Working memory model (Baddeley, 2007):

Liars draw on specific experiences or general schemas


Predictions:

Liars → more schema-consistent details

Truth-tellers → more schema-inconsistent/irrelevant details

Memory decay affects truth-tellers’ recall over time (Sporer, 2016)

title: Deception Lab
text:
Linguistic Cues to Deception

The Lie




Pronouns: fewer first-person pronouns (self-distancing)
Negations: more negations (denial)
Specificity: less specific (avoid details)
Temporal structure: less complex (cognitive load)
Emotion words: more negative emotion (anxiety/guilt)
Social words: fewer social words (avoid social connection)
Cognitive complexity: less complex language (cognitive load)
Certainty: more certainty (convince)



Tentativeness: more tentative (uncertainty)
Diversity: less diverse vocabulary (cognitive load)
Readability: less readable (cognitive load)
Quantity: fewer words (avoid details)
Qualifiers: more qualifiers (uncertainty)
Repetitions: more repetitions (convince)
Distancing: more psychological distancing (self-distancing)

text:
Definition & The Intentionality Debate

Theory











Core Definition


“A process by which one individual deliberately attempts to convince another person to accept as true what the liar knows to be false, typically for the liar to gain some type of benefit or to avoid loss.”
— Vrij (2000, p. 15)



The Intentionality Debate: Most definitions emphasize intentional deception (Chisholm & Feehan, 1977; DePaulo et al., 2003), though some argue lying can occur without intent to mislead (Smith, 2007).

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
The Deception Landscape

Theory

How often do people lie?

Diary studies: ~2 lies per day; 20–31% of interactions involve deception (DePaulo et al., 1996)
Distribution is highly skewed: ~5% of people tell ~50% of all lies (Serota et al., 2010, 2021)
Truth is the default: most people tell the truth most of the time

Why do people lie?

Lie aversion: people forgo gains to avoid lying (Abeler et al., 2012; Gneezy, 2005)
Motivations: self vs. other; gain vs. loss (DePaulo, 1996; Vrij, 2008)
“Butler lies” maintain relationships (Hancock, 2009)
More willing to lie for charity than self (Yin et al., 2017)

text:
Truth Bias & Detection Accuracy

Theory

The Truth Bias
People judge others as truthful more often than they actually are (Bond & DePaulo, 2006).
Explanations:

Spinozan mind: belief is automatic (Gilbert, 1991)
Truth-Default Theory: we default to truth (Levine, 2014)
Adaptive Lie Detector: functional decision-making (Street, 2015)

Human Detection Performance

~54% accuracy (chance = 50%) (Bond & DePaulo, 2006)
No reliable behavioral signal found (DePaulo et al., 2003)
Training, confidence, or profession have little effect (Aamodt & Custer, 2006)
Recent developments: active elicitation techniques show promise (Nahari, 2019; Vrij & Granhag, 2012)

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
Experimental Paradigms: Production

Methods

How do we get people to lie in the lab?

Cheating tasks — dice rolling, coin flipping, matrix tasks (Shalvi et al., 2011). Participants self-report outcomes with opportunity to inflate.
Mock crimes — participants “commit” a mock theft then are interviewed. Compares truthful vs. deceptive statements in forensic-like context.
False opinion paradigm — participants instructed to misrepresent attitudes or beliefs. Studies attitude misrepresentation.
Poker/strategic games — participants play poker hands or deception-based games in natural strategic context.
Faking friendship — brief micro-interactions where participants instructed to fake closeness. Studies social deception in relationships.

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
Experimental Paradigms: Detection

Methods

How do we measure detection ability?

Sender-receiver games — “Deception Olympics” paradigms where senders lie or tell truth; receivers judge veracity.
Interview coding — trained coders rate linguistic, nonverbal, or paralinguistic cues from recorded interviews.
AI vs. human judges — transcripts, audio, or video scored by both algorithms and human raters to compare performance.
Modality manipulations — same content presented via text, audio-only, video-only, or audio-visual to test channel effects.
Training interventions — pre-post designs testing whether training improves detection accuracy or shifts response bias.

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
Qualitative Methods

Methods

Qualitative approaches provide rich, contextual understanding:

Lie diaries (DePaulo & Kashy, 1998) — participants record all lies and social interactions over 7 days
Thematic analysis — identifying patterns in lie content, motives, targets, and outcomes
Narrative analysis — examining structure of lies over time; how liars construct false narratives
Discourse analysis — how lies are linguistically constructed; conversational patterns; power dynamics

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
Primary Reading: Vrij, Hartwig, & Granhag (2019)

Key Reading

Summary

This comprehensive Annual Review article examines nonverbal communication and deception detection. Key findings:

Nonverbal cues to deception are faint and unreliable (effect sizes typically d < 0.30)
Human detection accuracy is only ~54% (barely above chance of 50%)
Verbal cues are more diagnostic than nonverbal cues
People hold widespread misconceptions about deception cues (e.g., gaze aversion, fidgeting)
Visual-only detection is least accurate; audio-only is more effective
Training based on nonverbal cues produces minimal improvements
Theoretical frameworks include cognitive load, emotional leakage, self-presentation, and interpersonal deception theory
Future research should examine settings where nonverbal analysis is essential and develop more precise measurements

Critical insight: Despite popular belief and media portrayals, there is no “Pinocchio’s nose” — no reliable nonverbal sign of deception exists.

Reference
Vrij, A., Hartwig, M., & Granhag, P. A. (2019). Reading lies: Nonverbal communication and deception. Annual Review of Psychology, 70, 295–317. https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev-psych-010418-103135

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
Definition & The Intentionality Debate

Theory











Core Definition


“A process by which one individual deliberately attempts to convince another person to accept as true what the liar knows to be false, typically for the liar to gain some type of benefit or to avoid loss.”
— Vrij (2000, p. 15)



The Intentionality Debate: Most definitions emphasize intentional deception (Chisholm & Feehan, 1977; DePaulo et al., 2003), though some argue lying can occur without intent to mislead (Smith, 2007).

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
The Deception Landscape

Theory

How often do people lie?

Diary studies: ~2 lies per day; 20–31% of interactions involve deception (DePaulo et al., 1996)
Distribution is highly skewed: ~5% of people tell ~50% of all lies (Serota et al., 2010, 2021)
Truth is the default: most people tell the truth most of the time

Why do people lie?

Lie aversion: people forgo gains to avoid lying (Abeler et al., 2012; Gneezy, 2005)
Motivations: self vs. other; gain vs. loss (DePaulo, 1996; Vrij, 2008)
“Butler lies” maintain relationships (Hancock, 2009)
More willing to lie for charity than self (Yin et al., 2017)

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
Individual & Cultural Differences

Theory

Pathological lying: Compulsive, not goal-driven; linked to low self-esteem and neurocognitive deficits (Poletti, 2011)
Prolific liars: Score high in Machiavellianism; manage consistency well (Kashy & DePaulo, 1996; El Haj, 2017)
Culture matters:

Collectivist cultures: lie to protect relationships (Bessarabova, 2014; Park, 2018)
Individualist cultures: prioritize personal integrity
Frequent liars are not necessarily less moral (Halevy, 2014)

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
Truth Bias & Detection Accuracy

Theory

The Truth Bias
People judge others as truthful more often than they actually are (Bond & DePaulo, 2006).
Explanations:

Spinozan mind: belief is automatic (Gilbert, 1991)
Truth-Default Theory: we default to truth (Levine, 2014)
Adaptive Lie Detector: functional decision-making (Street, 2015)

Human Detection Performance

~54% accuracy (chance = 50%) (Bond & DePaulo, 2006)
No reliable behavioral signal found (DePaulo et al., 2003)
Training, confidence, or profession have little effect (Aamodt & Custer, 2006)
Recent developments: active elicitation techniques show promise (Nahari, 2019; Vrij & Granhag, 2012)

THE LIAR

Pieces of the Puzzle

Who lies?

Distribution: most lies by minority of prolific liars
Personality correlates: Machiavellianism, narcissism, psychopathy; low agreeableness
Contexts: authority vs. peers; online vs. offline; white lies vs. self-serving

Who is good at lying?
High Machs, actors, poker players are candidate “good liars” (Vrij, 2010; Verigin et al., 2019)
How do people lie?
Channels: face, body, voice, text | Strategies: faking good/bad, malingering, charm, feigned friendship
The experience of lying: Affective (guilt, anxiety, delight), cognitive (load, monitoring), social (trust dynamics, suspicion)
Qualitative opportunities: Interviews with prolific liars, diary studies, life history approaches

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
THE LIE

Pieces of the Puzzle

Linguistic Cues to Deception



Fewer first-person pronouns (self-distancing)
More negations (denial)
Less specific (avoid details)
Less complex temporal structure (cognitive load)
More negative emotion words (anxiety/guilt)
Fewer social words (avoid connection)
Less complex language overall
Variable certainty (convince vs. uncertainty)



Less diverse vocabulary (cognitive load)
Less readable (cognitive load)
Fewer words total (avoid details)
More qualifiers (uncertainty)
More repetitions (convince)
More psychological distancing


Important: These cues are probabilistic, not deterministic. Context matters.
Qualitative opportunities: Discourse analysis of lie construction, narrative analysis of structure, thematic content patterns

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
THE DETECTOR

Pieces of the Puzzle

Who is good at detecting lies?

High empathy and social skills may help
Training helps minimally
Humans achieve ~54% accuracy
“Wizards” exist but are rare (ten Brinke et al., 2014; Levinson, 2020)

What cues are used?

Linguistics: pronouns, negations, specificity, temporal structure
Nonverbal: illustrators, adaptors, gaze (generally weak and variable)
Physiology: heart rate, skin conductance (constraints & ethics)
Modality: audio, visual, audio-visual effects

The experience of being deceived: Betrayal, doubt, rumination, trust erosion, relationship damage
Qualitative opportunities: Interviews with expert detectors, think-aloud protocols, case studies, ethnographic observation

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
THE CONTEXT

Pieces of the Puzzle



Modality Effects

Meta-analyses show:

Audio-visual > audio or visual alone
Audio > visual (paralanguage cues)
Visual alone least effective
Text-based detection possible


Other Contextual Factors
Relationship dynamics:

Authority vs. peer relationships
Intimate vs. casual relationships
Online vs. offline contexts

Stakes and consequences:

High-stakes vs. low-stakes lies
Social vs. material consequences
Legal/forensic vs. everyday contexts

Culture:

Collectivist vs. individualist
Display rules for emotion
Acceptability of different lie types


Qualitative opportunities: Situational analysis, context mapping, comparative ethnography across cultures

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
Experimental Paradigms: Production

Methods

How do we get people to lie in the lab?

Cheating tasks — dice rolling, coin flipping, matrix tasks (Shalvi et al., 2011). Participants self-report outcomes with opportunity to inflate.
Mock crimes — participants “commit” a mock theft then are interviewed. Compares truthful vs. deceptive statements in forensic-like context.
False opinion paradigm — participants instructed to misrepresent attitudes or beliefs. Studies attitude misrepresentation.
Poker/strategic games — participants play poker hands or deception-based games in natural strategic context.
Faking friendship — brief micro-interactions where participants instructed to fake closeness. Studies social deception in relationships.

title: Deception Lab 3
text:
Experimental Paradigms: Detection

Methods

How do we measure detection ability?

Sender-receiver games — “Deception Olympics” paradigms where senders lie or tell truth; receivers judge veracity.
Interview coding — trained coders rate linguistic, nonverbal, or paralinguistic cues from recorded interviews.
AI vs. human judges — transcripts, audio, or video scored by both algorithms and human raters to compare performance.
Modality manipulations — same content presented via text, audio-only, video-only, or audio-visual to test channel effects.
Training interventions — pre-post designs testing whether training improves detection accuracy or shifts response bias.

Primary Reading: Denault et al. (2022)

Key Reading

Summary

This bibliometric overview analyzes over 100 years of social science research on deception and lying. Key findings:

7,290 English-language articles identified from Web of Science (1900-2022)
Research accelerated dramatically: 44.5% of all articles published 2010-2019
Top journal: Applied Cognitive Psychology (2.15% of articles)
Research is highly interdisciplinary: psychology, economics, law, criminology, neuroscience
Leading author: Aldert Vrij (201 articles); most cited: Bella DePaulo (159 citations/article)
Most used keywords: behavior, lie detection, information, cues, accuracy
Critical gap: Organizations like TSA adopted unfounded “behavioral analysis” programs (e.g., SPOT) despite lack of scientific evidence
Research extends beyond lie detection to: children’s lying behavior, dishonesty, self-deception, interviewing techniques
Major challenge: Communicating scientific findings to practitioners who face “immediate and easy solutions to complex challenges” from pseudoscientific sources

Critical insight: Despite substantial scientific knowledge, misconceptions about deception persist in practice, media, and large organizations—sometimes with costly consequences ($212M annually for SPOT program).
